intro: Astragalus lentiginosus var. scorpionis, commonly known as the scorpion milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its distinctive, spiny stems and small, yellowish to greenish flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces pods that contain several seeds. It is adapted to harsh, dry environments and is often found in rocky soils and desert landscapes. The species is part of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is known for its ability to fix nitrogen in the soil.
